top_comments.comment: I just want to hang out with you two. I think your enthusiasm is infectious. I love your personal comments. I will bring the beer and listen to clips for an evening?

Hey guys,  Last Night of the Proms “Jerusalem”. Words William Blake/Milton n music Hubert Parry.  Check out the composition it’s beautiful. Back in the 80’s on the river in Cambridge, as the punt in front of us stopped under a bridge, a girl got up from the stern and sang Jerusalem. Phenomenal acoustics. It was a golden moment that still transports me to another world.

comments_since_last_sample.body: Mahler - Symphony No. 4 is the most beautiful one,  impressed me the most.

I was driving this morning while listening to you guys. Then you mentioned Prokofiev and Yuja Wang and played my favourite piece... I never had my forehead, backhead, arm and back rised for that long, like, 10+ seconds. Such intense anticipation!
And the Britton and Debussy and Mahler parts are  also interesting
Wow that Kapustin!! And so glad to see recognition for some of Sibelius piano works
I just want to hang out with you two. I think your enthusiasm is infectious. I love your personal comments. I will bring the beer and listen to clips for an evening?
I liked the video. Sir C. Hubert H. Parry 1848-1918, wrote "Jerusalem", the UK's 2nd national anthem. Sullivan, Elgar, Parry, etc, all wrote exquisite little choral pieces, including church music.

I thought I'd respond as the obscure list proceeds to see how many I've heard and can recognize.
1:20 Danse Sacre et Profane Debussy. I've heard it on Youtube and perhaps on the radio.
3:30 Prokofiev Piano Concerto No. 3 - I'm not sure I've heard it before. I don't find his music memorable.
5:50 Benjamin Britten I haven't heard him before.
9:00 Mahler's 4th I don't think I"ve heard it, but I like it.
10:10 Sibelius I haven't heard it before.
11:00 Schuman quartet New to me.
12:00 Kapustin Never heard before.
14:17 Parry New I like it.
15:50 Debussy New I like it.

Just 1 out of 10. How about you?
